1:24 Hold up. Is this the mass effect (from the game, Mass Effect)?


The mass effect, as defined in the game, is a change in an object's mass, caused by a mass effect field. These fields are created by running an electrical current through the fictional substance "element zero".


You can cool things to super low temperatures by running a current through...well, whatever machine scientists use to cool things to super low temperatures. Have we found a real element zero? Or is there something you're glossing over?

Because we Human Beings are made up of Atoms (Human Body is roughly; 7 Trillion, Trillion atoms) we look at things relative to OUR size.  Actually, the subatomic world is where the really exciting things are happening.  A single Planck Length is as much smaller than the period of this sentence as the period at the end of this sentence is smaller than the Observable Universe.  We are actually HUGE in relation to all the things in the Subatomic World that we think of as being "small".  It's ALL just relative.  We should be devoting a LOT more money to Microscope Technology than we currently spend on Space Craft and Telescopic Technology...

There's no such thing as "a Lego", so how has "Legos" become a word? If all lego bricks looked roughly the same, I could see how this would come about, but nobody used the word "Legos" back in the 50s when they did look similar, so how has it emerged as a word this century now that there is such a wide variety of pieces? I have no idea, but bear in mind that these videos are likely to attract the kind of people who are distracted from the central content by trivial technical inaccuracy.

What do you mean by "almost everything in the universe is made up of particles"? Only 3 percent of everything is made up of standard particles, the rest have to be shoved under the broad category of dark matter and dark energy. Or if you are considering empty space (which may or may not be quantacized into particles, albeit nonstandard ones), you get pretty much everything being something other than particles.

So when we see the universe as bigger and bigger it is not really a matter of distance but a perception of a slowing C that might be due to a time dilation.

What I mean is that since the beginning of time, there was no big Bang, but a Slowing down of the C (speed=space/time) so at the very beginning (T ≈ 0) "C=infinite", so a subatomic particle moving at C could cross almost the entire of the universe in that tiny fraction of T.

And then, when C slowed down a bit the matter gathered :)

My conclusion is just that Time is expanding, not the space. And there is not Dark energy at all. I lack the resources to put this on numbers, but is very easy to explain in fact. Thanks for reading.
109th view Yay ! lol

Hi Henry.

Your video is awesome, as usual. I know it's not the point of your video, but the Higgs boson event display portrayed twice therein is just an early simulation. As of today we have real images of Higgs boson events. May you not know where to find them (originals I mean), drop me a line (p.e. on twitter @pagarab).

Also, not that I feel offended but saying experimental particle physics is like to "wait and see what nature has in store" (2:26) could sound somewhat discouraging for young students who might feel interest in the field. In fact, we give nature a twist so the right conditions are met for new particles to pop up. And not only those we are almost sure of finding, like the Higgs boson, but also the ones we simply dream of, like dark matter or supersymmetric particles. As exciting as quasiparticle physics is, experimental particle physics is not left behind. Embarking in such a quest is a hell of ride !

Keep up with you great videos. Not sure I can live without them ! ;)

The most exciting discovery is not simply the first observation of a fundamental particle, but the observation of a fundamental particle that no one had ever predicted.  The Higgs Boson was already predicted by the standard model.  On the other hand, if we discover something that was not predicted, this would force us to reevaluate our understanding of the fundamental laws of physics.

I don't mind emergent particles--in fact, emergence in general is my favorite thing in the universe--but it irks me to talk about them as though they're actual particles when they're not. Especially electron holes, because that's like talking about "particles of darkness" or "cold energy". It's just confusing to talk about a lack of a thing as though it were a thing itself.
